body: Hi @orichalque I'm trying to reproduce your bug, which version of Spoon did you try?

Ok, I don't manage to reproduce your bug in a simple test case right now. Could you try with version 5.7.0 and also try to remove the annotation on the constructor of `BooleanArrays`, just to check if it's related or not.

I just saw that your error message show a weird path: 
>The constructor BooleanArrays() is not visible at **C:\Users\...\eclipse\BooleanArraysBaseTest.java**

It should be in **internal** directory at least, no?

I'm going to try using Spoon 5.7.0.
And the path is weird indeed, since it is the root folder of my eclipse.

I'm launching the spoon instrumentation from an Eclipse Plugin, it this is of any help.

> I'm launching the spoon instrumentation from an Eclipse Plugin, it this is of any help.

Do you know if the eclipse plugin you're using move the files before launching Spoon? Because it looks like the hierarchy of your Java file is wrong, leading to the error.

I'm doing multiple operations before instrumenting the source code, including reverse-engineering, with the MoDisco framework, and Model Transformations. But, as far as I know, I'm not moving any files or folder. 

Nonetheless I managed to instrument several other projects with Spoon, using the same configuration.
I'll try to reproduce the error using only Spoon on the project I shared in my first message.

I wrote a quick Eclipse plugin launching a Spoon instrumentation available [here ](https://github.com/orichalque/SpoonPlugin/blob/master/src/spooneclipseplugin/instrumenter/SpoonInstrumenter.java)

When running it on the project sample I presented earlier, I have the exact same error, still with the following exception: 
```
Caused by: spoon.compiler.ModelBuildingException: The constructor BooleanArrays() is not visible at C:\Users\user\eclipse\modeling-neon\eclipse\BooleanArraysBaseTest.java:23
	at spoon.support.compiler.jdt.JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.report(JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.java:580)
	at spoon.support.compiler.jdt.JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.reportProblems(JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.java:561)
	at spoon.support.compiler.jdt.JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.compile(JDTBasedSpoonCompiler.java:158)
	at spoon.Launcher.run(Launcher.java:658)
	at spooneclipseplugin.instrumenter.SpoonInstrumenter.instrument(Unknown Source)
```
The same error happens when removing the  `@VisibleForTesting` annotation.

However I noticed than when changing the visibility of the `test.BooleanArrays` constructor to public, the exception doesn't happen anymore. Which is strange, because only the `internal.BooleanArrays` constructor is called. 

Edit: Using the option `launcher.getEnvironment().setAutoImports(false);` wont throw exception during the compilation.

> I wrote a quick Eclipse plugin launching a Spoon instrumentation available here

I don't manage to run the plugin, apparently it requires that a "lib" directory to be present in the sample project? 

> However I noticed than when changing the visibility of the test.BooleanArrays constructor to public, the exception doesn't happen anymore. Which is strange, because only the internal.BooleanArrays constructor is called.

It really looks like your plugin somehow messed up the project between `test.BooleanArrays` and `internal.BooleanArrays`. Did you try to reproduce the error in command line?

So, I finally managed to run your plugin in debug, and indeed the problem is not located in `internal.BooleanArrays` but in `test.BooleanArrays` I'm not sure yet, where the problem comes from, but it may be related to the use of JDT. 
At least I can reproduce it, so I will investigate.

rename.from: Exception at compilation due to a constructor with default visibility
rename.to: Exception at compilation due to a constructor with private visibility

body:
> I don't manage to run the plugin, apparently it requires that a "lib" directory to be present in the sample project?

Indeed, I put all the jar in a single /lib/ folder, for the `setSourceClasspath(/* an array with jars */);`, 
Since I have no quick way to get all the jar from Maven. 
I forgot to give you the [link ](http://ovh.to/npHYwdK)of the project with the lib folder.

I'll try to run the plugin using command line as soon as possible. Since now I only ran Spoon programmatically.

Thank you for your help

issue.title: Variable called "java" messes with the imports

repository.name: spoon
repository.description: Spoon is a metaprogramming library to analyze and transform Java source code. :spoon: is made with :heart:, :beers: and :sparkles:. It parses source files to build a well-designed AST with powerful analysis and transformation API.

issue.body:
Hello,
I'm Spooning the JUnit4 source code, and in the [following class](https://github.com/junit-team/junit4/blob/master/src/test/java/junit/tests/runner/TextRunnerTest.java), a variable has been named "java": 

`String java = System.getProperty("java.home") + File.separator + "bin" + File.separator + "java";`

I configured my launcher with `launcher.getEnvironment().setAutoImports(false);`, after running the launcher, the following code is generated: 

`java.lang.String java = ((((java.lang.System.getProperty("java.home")) + (java.io.File.separator)) + "bin") + (java.io.File.separator)) + "java";`

Which is completely normal, but the compilation will fail because "java.lang.System" refers to the "java" String declared earlier, which has no "lang" attribute (obviously).

Since my previous issue I'm running Spoon using `launcher.getEnvironment().setAutoImports(false);`.

Since it is quite specific, I'm renaming the Java variable in the source code, but it can be a bit time-consuming, when there's multiple classes with a similar variable.

Thibault

issue.body:
Hi everyone,

we plan to release a new version of Spoon this week, probably wednesday (31/05) or thursday (01/06).
It will contain a bunch of bug fixes and new features :-)

Thanks all for your bug reports and PRs, and welcome to the newcomers in Spoon. 
More information about the changelog on this thread soon.
